detail.content: Guided Visits & Study Trips, Spanish and Portuguese | NYU                                Navigation           NEW YORK UNIVERSITY       ARTS AND SCIENCE       COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE       GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                                Back to Home       Guided Visits & Study Trips   An integral part of the core curriculum and orientation program, visits   and study trips give students the unique opportunity to investigate   Spanish culture in situ. In recent years students in the program have enjoyed:  On-site classes in the Museum of the Americas , with its unique collection of art and artifacts from across the Americas, and the Reina Sofía Museum , Spain’s leading modern and contemporary art museum. Other classes and lectures have been held at the Circle of Fine Arts in Madrid, the Prado Museum , and the CaixaForum Cultural Center, among other locations around Madrid. A three-day study trip to the Bilbao and San Sebastián    in the spring, “Urban Transformations: From Industrialization to   Postmodernism” focuses on modern and contemporary culture in the Basque   Country. Complemented with a lecture on the roots of Basque nationalism,   students learn about the region’s political tensions while studying the   social transformation of both cities. Students also visit the   Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao and are guided by professors on a walking   tour through Bilbao’s architectural transformation. A two-day study trip to Andalusia    in the fall, “From Al-Ándalus to the New World” gives students the   opportunity to study the wealth of cultural sites in Seville from the   Reconquest to the height of Imperial Spain. Visits to these major sites   are combined with guided tours of the Jewish quarter, the Cathedral and   Royal Alcazares, and a particularly impressive opportunity to hear about   daily life in a cloistered convent. A one-day study trip to Toledo ,   seat of the famous School of Translators founded by King Alfonso X el   Sabio, and a unique scenario in which to evaluate the legacy of the   “three cultures” of medieval Spain, with its great Gothic cathedral, two   synagogues (one housing the Sephardic Museum), and mosque. A one-day study trip to Segovia ,   where students are guided by faculty experts who lead them through a   historical itinerary of Roman architecture to the city walls and Alcázar   built in the Middle Ages. A visit to the Teatro Clásico Nacional to see a production of Golden Age theater by one of Spain’s most established companies.
